Author: code
Content:
It's an extremely tough spot to be in if your significant other isn't the type who understands or is willing to put up with startup life (mostly the lack of time for each other). While it can work, often it doesn't.

I've been down this road quite a few times. To me, it really is more of a matter of asking is this person right for me if our lifestyle choices conflict. So in essense, the startup almost always win.

Author: PakG1
Content:
You cite only non-fiction reference material in your examples. I'd say that the book has more staying power in fiction. There's just something nice about reading a book to relax, curled up on your couch by the fireplace. That's different from opening a book to learn/check something you need for work.

The kindle and ipad do well enough to replace physical books for curling up by the fireplace, but the abstract concept of the book seems safe to me, for fictional pieces at least. Of course, none of us can really know until we get to the future. :)

Author: listic
Content:
I don't know how many of the countries this reshipping service actually covers, but they don't ship to Russia, possibly to the whole ex-USSR. ("We currently do not ship to the country you chose" for Russian Federation, "No rate was found. Please contact our customer service." for Belarus and Ukraine)

I think one could use a better reshipping service: if you outsource reshipping anyway (and make your customers sign up for a separate, paid service at that), why not cover all countries as well?

Author: ay
Content:
TCP minions is there to solve precisely this problem:

http://dedis.cs.yale.edu/2009/tng/papers/pfldnet10-slides.pd...

TCP over TCP works well enough as soon as your packet loss is small enough to be within the fast retransmit. As soon as you have to timeout, all bets are off.

Content:
I'm pragmatic as well. What I find frustrating about this blatant Google fanboy-ism is that it is hypocritical on its face: any normal company thing they do gets trumpeted as "don't do evil! Weeeeee!" and every evil thing is defended with pragmatism.

They're just a big public tech company. They're no more good/evil than Apple, Microsoft or anyone else and it's really frustrating watching otherwise intelligent adults behaving as though they were somehow different.

Author: sajidnizami
Content:
Gap of about 20ms between compiled Linq2SQL and this looks enticing. I guess this can be used at hot spots with optimized SQL queries using existing LINQ2SQL entities.

Definitely not for everyone. The whole reason it exists perhaps is to kill SQL translation time and avoid dealing with data readers.

Kudos for making it OSS.

Also, Entity Framework takes about 800ms unoptimized. That is almost a second to execute a query. I can't begin to imagine what the performance of its solution would be in the hands of a new developer.

Edit: I misread about the EF performance. Sorry about that.

Author: schrototo
Content:
I've had a sleep cycle alarm clock for a couple of years now (they've been available long before this WakeMate thing, and mine also collects sleep data, altough I guess the WakeMate interface is much nicer) and although it kinda works, don't expect to wake up refreshed if you're shortchanging yourself on sleep. If you're only getting 5 hours of sleep a night you're going to wake up tired no matter what.

Since most of the time I don't really have to get up at a specific time, I usually let myself be woken up by the sunlight, which is the most consistently effective way of waking up refreshed that I've found.

Author: anon1385
Content:
I'm reminded of Alan Kay talking in 1987[1] about GRAIL (Graphical Input Language) on the RAND Tablet, which he calls the first "data tablet":

"When I saw that, and used it for half an hour in 1968, I felt like I was sticking my hands right through the display and actually touching the information structures directly. This was the first system I'd ever used, and practically the only one since, that I've called truly intimate. It was this degree of intimacy that was so important in a user interface."

Interestingly he mentions that one of the reasons for the creation of the RAND Tablet was that their economists and other computer users complained that they couldn't type.

[1] http://www.archive.org/details/AlanKeyD1987 Alan Kay: Doing with Images Makes Symbols GRAIL part starts at about 23:40

Author: kaitnieks
Content:
It wasn't like they were showing the failure with the sounds and the proclaimed that the car doesn't work. From what I remember, Jeremy said that car has overheated and has reduced power (then they showed car stopping at the side of the track with the sound, which sounded very much like sound-over effect instead of make-believe real sound). At the time I thought that stopping because of overheating is normal and can happen to any car on the race track.

The "does not work" came later, near the end of the segment, and it was clearly stated, that the car does not work in the real life (because of the charging times), not that it doesn't work literally.

Author: g6pay
Title: G6Pay - iPhone advertising network is hiring
Content:
G6Pay is hiring web developers and software engineers\nFULL TIME POSITIONS

Background: G6pay is an angel backed Pay-Per-Install Advertising Network for the iOS/Android. We work with some of the top gaming studios as well as brand name advertisers. We’re currently making revenue as well as profitable since launch.

We’re currently a team of three people and we’re looking for talented and excited individuals to join our team. This is a great opportunity for people who are looking for an unstructured, start up environment and are excited about thinking, developing, and executing on ideas within very short time frames. Self-starter attitude with a strong desire to learn in an always-changing environment is required. If you want to join a profitable and fast-growing start up in its early stage, shoot us an email!

Experience developing web application and working with Linux is a necessity. The perfect candidate would be comfortable with object-oriented PHP, common software design patterns, git, and managing a LAMP server at a junior level. Familiarity with Zend Framework is a big plus. Knowledge of internet advertising and previous experience preferred but not required.

Specific requirements:

advanced level proficiency in PHP 5.2/5.3

ability to manage Linux server from a terminal

good knowledge of MySQL and optimizing SQL queries for performance

developing extensions for PHP in C/C++ a plus

knowledge of Objective C and developing iPhone applications a big plus

knowledge of Java and developing Android applications a big plus

Knowing 20+ vim key combinations will put you on top of our list :).

Compensation:

Unlimited Brita water

Unlimited Spike Shooter (Energy Drink)

Good Pay

Option Plan

Benefits:\nFlexible Hours

Please email: support@g6pay.com or call (617)595-0787

Author: csomar
Content:
It doesn't have any meaning, at least for me. If your aim, when you started to learn, was to follow a CS course (say, MIT courses), then you are going to have an equal knowledge. If your aim was to build your first web site and do HTML/CSS/JS and PHP stuff, then you are going to learn it and do it.

You cannot know everything anyway, no? And CS courses differs from an university to another. The benefit of being self-taught is that you choose the materials yourself and you are enlightened when you study it.

Title: Autobiographical essay means
Content: Writing an autobiographical essay is an enjoyable task. However, students should keep in mind that it is not easy. They need to include insights into who they are, what their aspirations are etc which is not easy to include for some students.

Author: bonch
Content:
If you think problems with PCs is an exception to the rule, you're living in a dream world. The point is that, on a tablet, your parents wouldn't have had to go through the hassle of installing slow antivirus software or "manage to install" things. Installation and uninstallation is so simple that the PC method of multistep installers and uninstallers immediately looks incredibly archaic.

There are other tasks like managing photos, watching and editing movies, installing third-party software, and more that I bet your parents have trouble with or flat-out avoid on a PC. These things are easy on an iPad. Not to mention the constant threat of malware, no matter how paranoid your mom is.

If there's a totem that geeks cling to, it's the fear of the PC going away and the fantasy that PCs aren't overly complicated to an embarrassing degree, or that everyone can magically learn how to use PCs if they'd just spend hours every night on them like geeks do. It's symptomatic of a real lack of perspective when it comes to how the public deals with the standard PC. You and I think they're easy because we spend most of our time on them. They are our living or our hobby. Most people aren't like that.
